posts.name: Martin Delille
posts.cooked:
Did someone ever thought about creating a Qt application for signal?

We currently have three different app:

  • Android
  • iOS
  • Desktop

Qt would allow to develop share a big part of the code base.

Only the interface would be different between mobile and desktop but QML allow to design very nice UI very quickly!

I know this can represent a huge task but it would save a lot of time in the future.

Performance issue would also be greatly enhanced: I have a recent Macbook pro and Signal desktop take a very long time to load.

EDIT by moderator:
as there where many threads discussing platforms other than electron for the desktop app we’ve unified them here.
the original topic was about using Qt for a cross platform build and below we’ve added discussion about the usage of GTK

posts.name: Alexander Yngling
posts.cooked:
Another option could be Xamarin, allowing a shared codebase for many platforms, such as iOS, Android, Windows Desktop, OSX, Xbox, Tizen, Android Wear, Apple Watch etc etc.

(Disclaimer: I build Xamarin apps and love the framework.)

posts.name: Trolldemorted
posts.cooked: If you want to build an app with xamarin, you might be able to re-use lots of sourcecode from Signal-Windows. We decided to target uwp only though, because the other platforms already have enough clients.

posts.name: Martin Delille
posts.cooked: What language is Xamarin using?

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked: AFAIK C#. Plus some huge libraries that make the app huge, so I would prefer to keep the Android version in the current Java (also because I don’t know Kotlin).

posts.name: Alexander Yngling
posts.cooked: C#. I feel huge is a strong word, but they are a little bigger, yes (e.g. my latest Xamarin app, an app built for Red Bull, was about 25 mb for Android).

There are two distinct issues here, methinks. First, there is the question of whether signal client-apps should ALL be developed under a single unified cross-platform-framework such as qt5 + qml, or theoretically (more on this below) under xamarin-fka-gomono. The endgoal there would involve eventually replacing signal4android written in Java, signal4ios written in a combination of swift&objectiveC, and signal4desktop written in nodeJs-on-top-of-electron-on-top-of-forked-chromium. So this is a ton of work to get going (it involves rewriting and retesting and re-performance-tuning stuff for ALL the supported platforms: several versions of android + ios + several versions of windows + macos + debian based linux distros). And in the medium run, it would be necessary to simultaneously support all the ‘legacy’ codebases while the transition to the newly-created XPF-codebases was happening. There are a lot of risks here, in other words, that the rewrite-all-the-things approach would not merely fail to save time in the long-run, but that there might BE no long-run.

Now, the second question-slash-big-picture-issue, is whether or not it makes sense to replace the current signal4desktop (which is electron-based and thus cross-platform across windows + macos + debian-based linux distros) with either qt5 or xamarin XPFs. This would be less work, and involve less risk: instead of transitioning three major signalapp projects to the new XPF codebase, only one project (signal4desktop) would be transitioned. Instead of transitioning all the mobile platforms and all the desktop platforms, only the desktop platforms would be in transition. This is still a high-risk scenario, but no longer a very-high-risk scenario. And indeed, signal4desktop just underwent exactly such a transition, around November-2017-through-September-2018 during the changeover from signal4desktop-the-chromeApp to the new ‘standalone’ signal4desktop-the-nodeJs-app-based-on-electron-and-forked-chromium. So it CAN be done… but since it just WAS done you might not find much appetite for yet-another-big-rewrite of signal4desktop (let alone the much riskier rewrite-all-the-things scenario above).

Xamarin is basically ruled out as ever being “politically feasible” as a client-language. The company is owned by Microsoft, which is a direct competitor to signalapp in the form of skype and skypeForBiz-fka-Lync. They are hostile (down from ‘very hostile’) to any kind of open source, and are still very hostile to GPLv3 and AGPLv3 license that signalapp uses for all the normal stuff. True, openWhisperSystems is already working with Microsoft on a project to incorporate the dual-licensed version of signal-protocol into some future release of skype (plus maybe skypeForBiz), so there is an existing business relationship, but I don’t think there is any way Microsoft would re-license the xamarin-framework as GPLv3 just to allow openWhisperSystems rewrite signal4desktop. Politically infeasible, methinks, in short.

The situation with Qt5 is more interesting: apparently the latest v5.11 of Qt Quick now includes a version of the Quick Compiler for the LGPLv3 / GPLv3 flavors of Qt5, whereas before it was only available in the proprietary-portion of the dual-licensed Qt5 codebase. As for the corporate political feasibility, the folks behind Qt have gradually been moving further and further into the dual-licensed-GPL-for-everybody-and-proprietary-for-paying-customers business model since 2000. They were briefly owned by Nokia, but left prior to Microsoft acquiring the bulk of that Nokia brand, and as of May 2016 the Qt Company fka Trolltech is no longer owned by anybody and thus an independent entity for the most part. Whether the dual-licensing by Trolltech of Qt5, and the dual-licensing by OpenWhisperSystems of signal4desktop, can be made to cooperate… that is the political question, but it seems likely to be feasible “on paper” at least.

Qt5 is primarily C++ based, but since 2012 they have also offered fully-supported built-in Javascript-bindings in the QtQuick / QML portion of the framework. So it would not be impossible to imagine going from the current nodeJs-on-electron signal4desktop to either the QtWebEngine (based on chromium much like electron), or even all the way to QtQuick+QML. That latter transition would presumably speed things up on desktops, since the QtQuick framework ought to – again “on paper” – be speedier and more performant than electron. So in addition to being probably-politically-feasible, and probably-technologically-feasible, there is potentially even a conceivable “business-case” to make this shift.

It is still a huge amount of work though! So there is an opportunity cost involved here: is it more important to do Yet Another Major Framework-Transition with signal4desktop, going from signa4chromeApp to signal4electron in 2017/2018 and now to signal4qtWebEngine or signal4qtQuickQml during 2019/2020? Or is that time better-spent on optimizing and tuning the current signal4electron codebase? One strategic consideration is that, in the long run, it might be possible to eventually unify the entire signalapp codebase, such that signal4android and signal4ios could someday become Qt5-based apps, rather than native-platform-apps as they currently are, but I see that as a very-high-risk prediction (per above).

p.s. One particular opportunity-cost is that trying to rewrite signalapp into Qt5 (or less-feasibly-politically into Xamarin) keeps us from devoting resources to creating signal4ncurses as a command-line-interactive-version of the signalapp client, as well as someday writing a native version of signal4windowsPhone devices to compete with whatsapp there (often running on Nokia-branded hardware). Xamarin theoretically supports ‘headless console applications’ as an alternative to ncurses, and probably also offers WindowsPhone support as a Microsoft subsidiary, but per the licensing issues mentioned above is not really feasible. It is possible to write interactive CLI apps in Qt5 as well: [1] or [2] for instance. There is no qt5-for-WinPhone as yet, though they have support for WinCE + deprecated WinMobile, so possibly it will happen someday.

posts.name: Alexander Yngling
posts.cooked: Thank you for a good explanation of the political issues, @5_c_d , I understand more of the bigger picture now.

yngling:

the political issues

Don’t let those discourage you. If you are interested in working on signal4xamarin, you are definitely free to do so – all the available signalapp client-code is GPLv3, after all. Trolldemorted is working on an unofficial signal4windowsUwp native client targeting win10mobile + win10desktop, and you could have a lot of fun (and learn a lot) if you were to write a cross-platform signal4xamarin client targeting iphone+osx or android+linux or all of the above. It would, because of licensing-reasons and politics and such, never be very likely to get adopted as An Official Signal™ Client Thing… but perhaps, depending on your goals, so what? If you aren’t worried about that aspect, nothing wrong with full-speed-ahead :-)

MartinDelille:

I have a recent Macbook pro and Signal desktop take a very long time to load.

This is definitely a problem right now, but it is not primarily caused by nodeJs and electron framework-performance, there are some fundamental design-issues here. The signal-protocol requires messages be decrypted in the order they were received, and there is a single device-queue in signal-server right now which signal4desktop must process – in order sent, including all encrypted attachments, including read-receipts, and so on.

There are some signal4desktop-only-optimizations, and also some signal-server-coordinated-change solutions, but as a rule they are all tough to implement. You are not alone though:

  • Eliminate loading screen, load new messages in the background · Issue #1442 · signalapp/Signal-Desktop · GitHub
  • https://github.com/signalapp/Signal-Desktop/issues/1842#issuecomment-418489687
  • Why does the desktop app take ages to initialize itself?
  • Improve Signal Desktop startup time
  • Desktop client launch performance
  • What exactly is Signal Desktop loading/counting when launching it?

On a system where you HAVE already downloaded all your messages into signal4desktop, it should take a few seconds to load up the application. On the other hand, if you have NOT opened your signal4desktop in a week or a month, and there was a lot of message-traffic and read-receipt-traffic and attachment-file-transfers during that timespan, it can take many minutes to open signal4desktop (per architectural limitations mentioned above).

You can help prioritize speeding-up-signal4desktop work, by opening the various forum-threads and github-issues and ‘hearting’ or perhaps ‘plusOne-ing’ the suggested solutions that you would most appreciate seeing. It does not help to write a COMMENT which merely says ‘me also’ however since this sends out a bunch of emails to folks watching the threads… best to let the hardworking signal4desktop devs go about the business of optimizing performance, rather than distracting them with empty-commentary-emails (hearts/plusOne does NOT email anybody so those are helpful-to-prioritization-without-being-distracting).

In the meantime, best-practices is to have signal4desktop open and ready to rumble, if you are planning to use it – the speed-problems are generally related to having signal4desktop closed and thus getting mired in the message-backlog processing. Personally I use signal4desktop most of the time (real keyboard and large screensize which can display conversation-list as well as more of the recent messages in the selected conversation). If you don’t use it as often as myself, you can still keep it speedy by opening it “for no reason” once a day when you are about to head out for lunch or hit the sack, for instance. This will keep your backlog small, and thus, load-times relatively speedy when you DO need it.

If you are NOT seeing what I describe above (under ten seconds to load signal4desktop when there is no message-backlog … and well under a minute to load when there is less than 24 hours worth of messaging-backlog to churn through) then you should please open up a new forum-thread, with debuglogs and exact details of your platform and version and such.

posts.cooked:
Many good points have been made for both doing it and not doing it. I figured I’d throw in one more obvious one. If they share a good chunk of the codebase then it’s much easier to audit the code and fix bugs (at least as I understand it, I’m not a programmer but I get some of the concepts). It should also make it easier to fix bugs and add features when they come up too?

Would a huge rewrite be needed all at once or could it be done in steps? As in concentrate on the desktop versions first for Linux/Mac/Win and then work on the phone apps. I imagine it would be a long grueling process but I think in the end it would be worth it.

IDK, but in my view more clients are (usually) never a bad thing, so long as the majority agree on and use the official client. If someone comes up with a better solution I imagine people would switch to it and it’d be the new standard anyway.

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked:
anon36098184:

It should also make it easier to fix bugs and add features when they come up too?

I’m not a Qt developer myself so I can not be sure, but this need not be true. It is probably true for big errors in the UI flow, but those are not present in either client at the moment. I have read some of the Android code, and in some places it has constructs like (pseudocode)

if (Android version < 4.2) {
  do something
} else if (Android version < 4.4) {
   do something the KitKat way
} else if (Android version < 8) {
  do something similar but with Android 6, 7 specific constructs
} else {
   do something yet another way for Android 8 and 9
}

This will probably only become worse when more Android versions come available. If this also has to include several iOS, windows, MacOS and Linux versions the code becomes poorly readble and difficult to maintain.

posts.name: Martin Delille
posts.cooked:
I started a github project here:

GitHub

GitHub - MartinDelille/chat-qt: An service agnostic Qt chat client

An service agnostic Qt chat client. Contribute to MartinDelille/chat-qt development by creating an account on GitHub.

I might use this project as a QML learning project and would be happy in helping anyone who would like to learn C++/Qt/QML.
If you are not interested in making pull request, any kind of help is appreciated (I created a specific issue to gather contributors: Gather interested people · Issue #1 · MartinDelille/chat-qt · GitHub). Signal core knowledge will be necessary at a given time.
My first goal is to realize a front-end only application just to show how it can be easy to program.

There is a comment in this issue talking about a Qt client: https://github.com/signalapp/Signal-Desktop/issues/2178

I’ll be working on this project on the little spare time I have so be patient with me!

posts.name: Martin Delille
posts.cooked: (My last message is a little bit out of topic but it seems my account is block and I cannot create new post on the forum).

I think the potential bang for buck is a lot higher on replacing the desktop client with a Qt version than trying to do that with mobile clients. If nothing else, it would seem a good idea to do the desktop client first, since it’s the one that’s perpetually behind on features, full of bugs, performs poorly, and chews up gobs and gobs of memory.

Ncurses and Windows Phone (really?) are niche applications to say the least. But clients like this would already exist if Moxie wasn’t hostile to third party developers.

posts.name: Trolldemorted
posts.cooked:
pine4pinecones:

Ncurses and Windows Phone (really?) are niche applications to say the least. But clients like this would already exist if Moxie wasn’t hostile to third party developers.

Windows Phones like all UWP targets have Signal-Windows.

@qt: I would not recommend programming security-critical applications in an unsafe programming language

link_counts.title: GitHub - signal-csharp/Signal-Windows: Signal Private Messenger for Windows

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked:
Trolldemorted:

@qt: I would not recommend programming security-critical applications in an unsafe programming language

Which unsafe language? You do know in which language the libraries like curve 25519 and sqlcipher are programmed?

posts.name: Trolldemorted
posts.cooked:
johanw666:

Which unsafe language? You do know in which language the libraries like curve 25519 and sqlcipher are programmed?

Signal-Windows’ is pure c#, and I assume Signal-Desktop’s is pure javascript. I know Signal-Android uses a c implementation of curve25519, but only that component is in c, for good reason.

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked: Yes, the good reason is that Android development is done preferably in Java (or, recently, Kotlin). I don’t know any develpoment environments that allow to build Android apps in C++, certainly not at the time when TextSecure and Redphone were developed. We now have the C# option with Xamarin but that language has no real advantages over Java on the subject of buffer overflows and incorrect forced casts.

posts.name: Trolldemorted
posts.cooked:
johanw666:

Yes, the good reason is that Android development is done preferably in Java (or, recently, Kotlin).

They could also have implemented the underlying signal libraries in c - but programming something in c is just not a good idea if you don’t require crucial benefits like its performance and low-level development ease.

UI programming in general is error prone as hell, so I’d rather have a managed exception than a smashed stack and RCE vulnerabilities.
